p: Several authors have shown that the effectiveness of NTAP treatments decreases when dealing with high microbial loads. This fact has been shown in various substrates and for different microorganisms, including E. coli (Yu et al., 2006; Burts et al., 2009; Miao and Yun, 2011; Bermúdez-Aguirre et al., 2013), S. aureus (Burts et al., 2009), S. Typhimurium (Fernández et al., 2012), and S. cerevisae (Lee et al., 2006). However, in the case of bacterial spores the results are not so clear. Indeed, while some authors did not find differences in NTAP effectiveness depending on the initial spore concentration for different species of the genus Bacillus (Purevdorj et al., 2001; Lee et al., 2006), in a recent study, Butscher et al. ( 2016) observed that when the initial load of G. stearothermophilus spores in wheat grains was reduced from 10 7 to 10 6 cfu/g the degree of inactivation achieved through a 10 min NTAP treatment increased from 1.02 to 1.82 log units.
